arm_group.description: Swallowing evaluation with the Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing
Swallowing evaluation with the Videofluoroscopic Swallowing Study

brief_summary.textblock:
The main purpose of the study is to determine whether the Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation
      of Swallowing (FEES) is effective in detecting laryngeal penetration and tracheal aspiration
      when compared with the Videofluoroscopic Swallowing Study (VFSS) in bottle-feeding infants
      in the NICU. A secondary objective is to determine whether FEES can be used to detect
      laryngeal penetration and tracheal aspiration in breastfeeding NICU infants.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing FEES to VFSS in Diagnosing Laryngeal Penetration and Aspiration in Infants in the NICU

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  37 weeks or more postmenstrual age

          -  Diagnosis or suspicion of laryngeal penetration and/or tracheal aspiration by
             neonatal therapist and/or physician

          -  Inpatient at Baylor University Medical Center NICU

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Not medically stable enough to undergo both FEES and VFSS as determined by neonatal
             therapist and/or physician

          -  Bilateral complete cleft lip and palate

clinical_study.official_title: Determining the Efficacy of Using FEES Compared to VFSS to Diagnose Laryngeal Penetration and Aspiration in Infants in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU)

primary_outcome.measure: High sensitivity and specificity values for FEES

reference.citation: da Silva AP, Lubianca Neto JF, Santoro PP. Comparison between videofluoroscopy and endoscopic evaluation of swallowing for the diagnosis of dysphagia in children. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2010 Aug;143(2):204-9. doi: 10.1016/j.otohns.2010.03.027.
Leder SB, Karas DE. Fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing in the pediatric population. Laryngoscope. 2000 Jul;110(7):1132-6.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evidence of laryngeal penetration or tracheal aspiration during breastfeeding

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
